This CTL clone was shown to recognize this antigenic peptide from alternative reading frame of the human M-CSF (alt.M-CSF)4, and presented by HLA-B*3501. Epitope is encoded by DNA sequence 27262660 (GenBank ID) positions 240-281, which are part of an alternate reading frame of the gene coding for human M-CSF.

column5: Carlo Ciatto; Guido Capitani; Alain C Tissot; Frédéric Pecorari; Andreas Plückthun; Markus G Grütter
column8: Structural analysis of mycobacterial and murine hsp60 epitopes in complex with the class I MHC molecule H-2Db.
column22: The epitope possesses a non-standard PΩ anchor residue AlaP10 forming a set of conserved hydrogen bonds with MHC side chains. The peptide rises above the floor of the binding site and kinks between AlaP6 and SerP8. Consequently, AlaP7 is completely solvent-exposed. Only hydrogen bonds crucial for the conformation of C-terminal part of the peptide are discussed in the paper and curated. They result in an overall shift of the peptide backbone towards the alpha2-helix of MHC, when compared to other H-2D(b)-bound peptides.
column46: There are 4 similar complex molecules in the asymmetric structural unit. In the paper, the analysis is restricted to MolA, which is curate here.

column5: W Zhang; A C Young; M Imarai; S G Nathenson; J C Sacchettini
column6: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
column8: Crystal structure of the major histocompatibility complex class I H-2Kb molecule containing a single viral peptide: implications for peptide binding and T-cell receptor recognition.
column46: There are two MHC/Epitope complexes in the asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-microglobulin: B, epitope chain: E. Complex II : MHC alpha-chain: C,  beta2-microglobulin: D, epitope chain: F. There are no major differences between the two complexes. For the purposes of the paper an  averaged structure was used. Clear electron density was found for all the atoms in the epitope-binding groove, and more specifically for all the epitope residues. From the MHC molecule, only the first 270 residues of the alpha-chain were included in the structure, since the alpha-chain C-terminus was disordered.

column5: Michael Koch; Simon Camp; Trevor Collen; David Avila; Jan Salomonsen; Hans-Joachim Wallny; Andrew van Hateren; Lawrence Hunt; Jansen P Jacob; Fiona Johnston; Denise A Marston; Iain Shaw; P Rod Dunbar; Vincenzo Cerundolo; E Yvonne Jones; Jim Kaufman
column8: Structures of an MHC class I molecule from B21 chickens illustrate promiscuous peptide binding.
column46: There are two MHC/Epitope complexes in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-microglobulin chain: B, epitope chain: C. Complex II : MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-microglobulin chain: E, epitope chain: F. The 3-D crystal structure of the epitope assembled into a complex with BF2*2101 and beta2-microglobulin was solved to 2.6 angstroms. Positions 2, 8 and 10 of the peptide anchored the peptide, while the central residues (positions 4- 6) bulged out of the binding groove.

column5: B E Gewurz; R Gaudet; D Tortorella; E W Wang; H L Ploegh; D C Wiley
column6: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
column8: Antigen presentation subverted: Structure of the human cytomegalovirus protein US2 bound to the class I molecule HLA-A2.
column19: Human T-cell leukemia virus type I
column46: The crystal structure contains the MHC/epitope complex bound to the human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) glycoprotein US2 (Unique Short). The crystallographic asymmetric unit contains four copies the US2/MHC/Peptide complex. The following residues had a well ordered electron density and were included in the refined atomic model: MHC: 1-275, beta2-microglobulin 0-99, Tax epitope: 1-9, US2:43-137. No electron density was observed for US2 residues 15–42 and 138–140. The US2 binding site on the MHC molecule is distant from the epitope binding groove and does not affect the MHC/peptide binding.

column5: D R Madden; J C Gorga; J L Strominger; D C Wiley
column8: The three-dimensional structure of HLA-B27 at 2.1 A resolution suggests a general mechanism for tight peptide binding to MHC.
column22: For the formation of the MHC/Epitope complex, a collection of peptides that bind to this MHC was used. The epitope sequence is a peptide model that was built into the MHC/Epitope structure to represent the single, dominant main chain conformation of the bound peptides.
column46: There are two molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I: MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Complex II: MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. Each molecule in the asymmetric unit consists of residues 1-276 of the MHC heavy chain, 99 residues of beta2-m and 9 peptide residues. No electron density was found for side chains of MHC residues 108 and 268 and for the side chain of beta2-m residue 58. Very weak electron density was observed for MHC residues 220-229. For the crystallization of the MHC/Epitope complex, a co-crystallized collection of HLA-B27 peptides was used. As such, the electron density detected by the X-ray diffraction represents a superposition of the structures of the individual molecules found in the diffracting volume of the crystal. The peptide electron density observed represents a composite of the binding conformations of the different peptides in the co-crystallized population. Peptide electron density is clear for residue side chains of anchor positions P2, P3, and P9 (residues common to all peptides), weaker at variable side chain positions P1, P7, P8 and none found for residues P4, P5, and P6. A peptide model of sequence ARAAAAAAA was built into the structure to represent the single, dominant main chain conformation of the bound peptides.

It is an equally good agonist towards TCR AHIII12.2 from a CD8+ CTL clone derived from a C57BL/6 mouse injected with the human lymphoblastoid cell line JY. It was chosen over p1058 to maximize the primary sequence differences between the two MHC/Epitope complexes examined in this study. Epitope main chain density is relatively weak near residue P5. This may indicate some flexibility around the middle of the peptide.

Main chain conformations of the two molecules are essentially identical, but the side chain of P1 is rotated. Also, the side chains of residues P4, P6 and P7 adopt slightly different orientations in the two molecules.

column46: There are two molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex 1: MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Complex 2: MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. Electron density for the entire peptide in both molecules was continuous and clearly visible. Although main chain conformations of the two molecules are essentially identical, side chains of P4, P5, P7 and P8 show slightly different orientations. column5: Vesselin Mitaksov; Steven M Truscott; Lonnie Lybarger; Janet M Connolly; Ted H Hansen; Daved H Fremont
column8: Structural engineering of pMHC reagents for T cell vaccines and diagnostics.
column46: The crystal structure contains the MHC/Epitope complex as a single-chain trimer (SCT). This is the first generation of SCT (SCTwt) which was designed by linking the C-terminus of the peptide by using a (G4-S)3 linker to the N-terminus of beta2m and linking the C-terminus of beta2m to the N-terminus of the MHC using a (G4-S)4 linker. The final electron density map was of excellent quality for main chain or side chain atoms of the peptide. Interpretable density was also observed for the entire peptide-beta2m linker. No electron density was observed for the beta2m-MHC linker and for residues 278–280 at the C terminus of the MHC molecule. There are two molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2m chain: A, epitope chain: A. Complex II : MHC alpha-chain: B, beta2m chain: B, epitope chain: B.

column5: J A Speir; K C Garcia; A Brunmark; M Degano; P A Peterson; L Teyton; I A Wilson
column8: Structural basis of 2C TCR allorecognition of H-2Ld peptide complexes.
column22: The epitope is a nine-residue (P1–P9) polyalanine peptide model, based on the influenza nucleoprotein epitope bound to H-2-Db [PDB: 1HOC]. The clear side chain electron density allowed the placement of the anchor residues P2 and  P9 in the model, but the other residues were left as alanines.
column46: For the crystallization of the MHC/Epitope complex, the MHC with a mixture of bound peptide were used. Then, the crystal structure was used to construct two peptide models. Thus, the structure contains two peptide models in the MHC binding groove. The first model is a nine-residue (P1–P9) polyalanine peptide, based on the influenza NP epitope bound to H-2-Db [PDB: 1HOC]. The clear side chain electron density at P2 and P9 allowed the placement of these residues in the model, but the other residues were left as alanines. In the second peptide model, apart from the well defined P2 and P9 residues, the electron density for the remainder of the peptide indicated the presence of a broader range of residues compatible with known residue sequences of H-2-Ld binding peptides. Hence, the remaining residues were modeled after the  QL9 sequence. This peptide fit the electron density well. But, no single peptide model ideally represented the electron density of a peptide mixture. This assay refers to the first model.

column46: There are two MHC/Epitope molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Molecule 1 (MOL 1) : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Molecule 2 (MOL 2) : MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. Each MHC molecule in the asymmetric unit presents the peptide slightly differently. Residue P4 has different rotations in the two molecules, suggesting that this side chain is highly mobile. Residue P5 shows an alpha carbon shift of 0.5 Å. Also, residue P7 is particularly dynamic, as its side chain was refined in two different conformations in MOL 2. This assay refers to Molecule 1.

column5: Oleg Y Borbulevych; Francis K Insaidoo; Tiffany K Baxter; Daniel J Powell Jr; Laura A Johnson; Nicholas P Restifo; Brian M Baker

column36: Table 2, Figures 1, 2, 3, S1, S4, S5 and 2GTZ (molecule 1)
column46: There are two MHC/epitope molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Molecule 1 (MOL 1A, MOL 1B) : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Molecule 2 (MOL 2) : MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. Each MHC molecule in the asymmetric unit presents the peptide slightly differently. This structure shows the greatest main chain diversity, as the main chain in the center of the peptide in the first molecule occupies two discrete positions, termed MOL 1A and MOL 1B, with the alternative (MOL 1B) position occurring via large rotations in residue P4 of 147 degrees and in P5 of 207 degrees. Residue P5 shows an alpha carbon shift of 1.7 Å, in the three different epitope positions. The side of residue P4 shifts by an almost 180 degrees flip in the two molecules, suggesting this side chain is highly mobile. Also, residue P7 is particularly dynamic, as its side chain was refined in two different conformations in MOL 2. clear electron density was observed for each of the various peptide conformations. This assay refers to Molecule 1.

column46: There are two molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Complex II : MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. The two molecules form a dimer linked by a sulfate mediated salt-bridge. Also, a pseudo twofold axis, centered on the sulfur atom, is formed between residues A: R79 and A: R83 of the one molecule and their equivalents of the other molecule. The peptides in the two molecules retain conserved conformations with respect to the buried residues, but show significant differences around P4 and P6 due to the inherent flexibility of the exposed residues.

column5: Lindsay L Jones; Leremy A Colf; Alexander J Bankovich; Jennifer D Stone; Yi-Gui Gao; Choi Mui Chan; Raven H Huang; K Christopher Garcia; David M Kranz
column8: Different thermodynamic binding mechanisms and peptide fine specificities associated with a panel of structurally similar high-affinity T cell receptors.
column46: A platform Ld module containing only the alpha1 and alpha2 domains and five stability mutations (N30D, A49V, I66V, W97R, and K131R), called Ld-m31, was used for binding. There are two molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I : MHC alpha-chain: A, epitope chain: P. Complex II : MHC alpha-chain: B, epitope chain: Q. The beta2-m chain was missing from the MHC molecule. There was no discernible electron density  for the side chain of the central P5 residue. The peptide conformation in Complex I is similar to that of the TCR 2C with H-2-Ld/QL9 [PDB: 2OI9] structure, but in Complex II, the peptide structure is altered. Complex II contained large areas of the MHC molecule (residues 41-61 and 171-175) and the P2 of the peptide that did not contain adequate electron density to determine the structure. Moreover, the peptide region of Complex II had multiple contacts with the alpha2 helix of Complex I. In contrast, Complex I had good electron density throughout and the peptide region contained considerably fewer contacts with Complex II. For these reasons, only Complex I is used in the analysis.

column8: Predominant occupation of the class I MHC molecule H-2Kwm7 with a single self-peptide suggests a mechanism for its diabetes-protective effect.
column46: H-2Kb and H-2Kd, the allele naturally present in NOD mice, share 90 and 85% sequence identity with H-2Kwm7, respectively (Fig. 2A and B). Structural comparison of H-2Kb [PDB: 1KPU] and H-2Kd [PDB: 1VGK] with H-2Kwm7 in this complex with VNDIFERI peptide shows that the quaternary structure of H-2Kwm7 conforms to the canonical MHC fold (Fig. 3A). Crystallographic analysis did not provide an explanation for the remarkable conservation of Arg at P7 of the peptides purified from H-2Kwm7 molecules (Table 1; Fig. 1D), as this residue was found to be solvent exposed rather than serving as an anchor.

column46: The structure contains the TCR molecule binding to the peptide-MHC complex. This tertiary structure was also curated. There are four molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex I: MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C, TCR alpha-chain: D, TCR beta-chain: E. Complex II: MHC alpha-chain: F, beta2-m chain: G, epitope chain: H, TCR alpha-chain: I, TCR beta-chain: J. Complex III: MHC alpha-chain: K, beta2-m chain: L, epitope chain: M, TCR alpha-chain: N, TCR beta-chain: P. Complex IV: MHC alpha-chain: Q, beta2-m chain: R, epitope chain: S, TCR alpha-chain: T, TCR beta-chain: U. All TCR-MHC/epitope complexes had well ordered electron density, and the electron density at the TCR-MHC/epitope interface was unambiguous. The individual TCR and MHC/epitope components were almost identical in all complexes. But, there was a TCR-MHC/epitope dimer present in the crystal lattice, made by complexes A (complex I) and B (complex IV). These complexes have distinct conformations, with the TCR adopting two different docking strategies on the MHC/epitope complex that differed by 12 degrees. This rotation axis was parallel to the peptide binding groove, causing atomic shifts in excess of 7 Å, resulting in leaning of the TCR more toward the MHC alpha2-helix. This assay refers to Complex A (complex I).

Complex II: MHC alpha-chain: F, beta2-m chain: G, epitope chain: H, TCR alpha-chain: K, TCR beta-chain: L. One important difference between the two molecules is that MHC residue Q155, located at the interface between the MHC and the CDR2alpha, adopts two different conformations. In the first molecule (AV-wt1, complex I), it contacts S51 of CDR2alpha, while in the other molecule (AV-wt2, complex II), it points toward T94 of TCRalpha. This assay refers to the complex I (AV-wt1).

column5: J A Speir; J Stevens; E Joly; G W Butcher; I A Wilson
column8: Two different, highly exposed, bulged structures for an unusually long peptide bound to rat MHC class I RT1-Aa.
column46: There are two complexes in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each complex are: Complex A : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Complex B: MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. There is an approximate 7 degrees rotation between the alpha3 and beta2-m domains of Complex B relative to Complex A, due to crystal packing. The epitope adopts two completely different conformations in the two complexes. The N-terminal residues of the epitope in Complex A rise more swiftly out of the binding groove, compared to the more gradual rise of the same residues of the epitope in Complex B. There was continuous electron density for the epitope, except for the side chains of residues P7-P8 in Complex B. This assay refers to Complex B.

column46: HLA-A2.1:KILGJ(1)VFJ(2)V crystals were subjected to UV irradiation prior to vitrification and X-ray data collection. In the resulting structure, the electron density for residues 5−7, between the two cleavage sites has largely disappeared. This implies that cleavage has occurred at both sites and that the central part of the peptide has dissociated from the MHC class I protein. Notably, peptide residues Lys-1 to Gly-4 (KILG) and Val-9 remain bound in almost identical positions as in the non-exposed structure [PDB: 2X70].

column22: The epitope is a GP2 variant with mutations: I2 ->L2 and V5->L5. There are two MHC/Epitope molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. The epitopes in the two molecules are not equivalent and the orientation of the P5 side chain is different. As such, each epitope is curated separately. This is epitope from Molecule 1.
column24: Fragment of a Natural Sequence Molecule
column46: There are two molecules in the crystallographic asymmetric unit. PDB chains for each molecule are: Molecule 1 : MHC alpha-chain: A, beta2-m chain: B, epitope chain: C. Molecule 2 : MHC alpha-chain: D, beta2-m chain: E, epitope chain: F. There is clear electron density for the peptide terminal residues in both molecules. In molecule 1, the density is continuous over the peptide main chain but the side chain for residue P6 is undefined. In molecule 2, the electron density is broken at residues P6 and P7. The epitopes in the two molecules are not equivalent and the orientation of the P5 side chain is different. As such, each epitope is curated separately. This assay refers to Molecule 2.

column8: Different length peptides bind to HLA-Aw68 similarly at their ends but bulge out in the middle.
column16: unknown protein eluted from human MHC allele
column22: The epitope is from a collection of bound, endogenous peptides.The epitope sequence comes from models of residues E-V-A and A-R that were built for peptide positions P1, P2, P3 at the N-terminus and PC-1, PC carboxy terminal, respectively.
column46: The structure represents the average image from the collection of bound peptides of 9, 10, and 11 amino acids eluted from HLA-Aw68. There is clear electron density for the first three and last two residues of the peptides, but not for any of the in between residues. The middle part of the peptide density is sparse and unconnected, presumable representing an average of diverse conformations and/or length. Models of residues E-V-A and A-R were built for peptide positions P1, P2, P3 and PC-1, PC, respectively.

column46: The crystal structure of the epitope/HLA-A*02:01 complex was determined.  The complex was crystallized in the presence of LILRB1 (LIR-1, ILT2), a broadly expressed inhibitory receptor that recognises class I MHC with low affinity. The LILRB1 binding site on HLA-A2 involves the alpha3 and beta2m domains but does not involve the alpha1-alpha2 peptide-binding platform, and peptides crystallised in HLA-A2 are identical in conformation in the presence or absence of LILRB1.

column46: The crystal structure of the epitope in complex with HLA-A*0201 was determined. There are two complexes in the asymmetric unit. The conformation of the epitope in complex with HLA-A*02 was analyzed by NMR and compared to the binding of peptide ALGIGILTV with HLA-A*02. The ALG nonamer showed two distinct peaks compared to one peak for the epitope, indicating greater conformational heterogeneity for the center of ALG when bound to HLA-A*02.
